content.description: Classic straight-in fingers to ring-locks splitter, with the occasional thin hand jam. The crux is the first bit, with painful finger stacks and bad feet. Those hard, painful locks eventually give way to good thin-hand jams in pods that lead to a small bulge and the anchor.
content.protection: 1 .4 camalot, 4 .5 camalots, 5 .75 camalots. you could place a #1 camalot at the bulge. Big chain connecting bolts and a drilled angle.
content.location: Drive a little over a 1/2 mile up Grand Wash and park on the south side of the road. This is the splitter crack just right of the "Z" crack when looking north from the road. Anchors are visible from the road.

content.description: Definitely the best line at the crag. A distinct zig-zagging crack to the left of Thinner. Fairly sustained climbing with three distinct hard sections: 1) at the bottom getting to the first good stance, 2) at the traversing "Z" feature, and 3) the final fingery sprint to the anchor.
content.protection: 2 .5 camalots, alot of .75 camalots ( I placed 4), about 4 #1 camalots, 1 #2 camalot, 2-3 green aliens, 2-3 yellow aliens, a blue metolious master cam went in great at the top. anchor as of 10/10/08 was 1 bolt, 1 drilled angle...both looked bomber, although the angle has probably been there since the FA.
content.location: Drive up Grand Wash about a 1/2 mile or so and park just before the road narrows and dirt walls rise up on either side as you enter the canyon proper. There is a decent place to park on the south side of the road directly below the climbs. The wall is on the left hand side (north) of the canyon about 100 yards from the car. Terrible Two's and Thinner are obvious splitter cracks about 10 feet apart from each other. The practice cracks are to the right of Thinner in a small depression/alcovey thing and are hard to see from the road. To the left of Terrible Two's is the right facing, aptly named Soapstone Dihedral.

content.description: A right facing corner that starts off with .75 camalots and ends with #1's. The hard size is over after 10 feet or so, but the crux is dealing with the fine layer of dust coating the corner...ie: it is very slippery. A fun, short climb worth a go if you don't mind a little sand in your jam.
content.protection: 3 .75 camalots, 3 #1 camalots should be plenty. Two bolt anchor on right wall.
content.location: This is the short right facing corner 20 feet left of Terrible Two's.

content.description:
Climbs the left leaning crack 30 feet right from Pussy bolt. Start with good edges to reach the small to big hand crack. Short but fun !

5.10a on Falcon's. Good express climb to do with Pussy bolts while the family hike the Great Wash... Good base anchor can be done for the ones who want to rope solo.
content.protection: Up to BD #3 (can put a #4 before traverse left at the top, but not mandatory). Blue ballnutz can protect the start, but not mandatory too (start easier than it looks).
content.location: 30 feet right from Pussy bolt, on Windgate tower. Start at the base of a small boulder. The Windgate tower is a small tower with a square boulder on top, tower leaning on the big cliff on the right when driving to the Great Wash parking lot. Park in the wash on the right of the road. 1 min approach.

content.description: Except for the first and last 10 feet (both 5.easy), the climb is in fact quite clean, solid and fun.  Consistent fingers, with a few hand-sized pods.  A mix of jamming, laybacking and some face holds down low, then a nice .9-ish layback to anchors.  Drilled angle, knot-choc and a nut with good webbing and rings.  Pull your rope with care, as the crack will try and gobble it.

This route is not actually on "terrible two's" wall.  Instead, it ascends the left side of a leaning pinnacle south-west of "terrible two's" wall.  It's moderate, doesn't require a wall sized rack, and is right off the road.  Yes sir, I stole the "pussy bolt" in 1997, when I placed a 3.5" friend 4 inches to the right of the bolt.  I believe somebody was learning how to handdrill on this first ascent.  Fun route, very moderate.  I decided that by removed the pussy bolt, I will rename the route to "The Fixed Route."  After all, Tyler Phillips and I fixed this climb.  A few hand sized cams will get you up this route.  Lower from slings through two bolts.-tda
Free standing boulder that has 5 problem ranging from V0 to V8, all totally worthy problembs
content.location: Obvious thin, wafer shaped boulder on right side of Grand Wash abou 1/4 of a mile in.

climbs.name: Left and Right Practice Cracks
climbs.fa: Jocelyn Van Belle, Bob Van Belle, September 1993

content.description: These route are on the same side of "terrible two's" wall.  Except they are further (south).  Near the road, you'll see two cracks with a slung anchor atop.  The left crack is a great way to reach the anchors then top-rope the right crack.  The rock is very solid windgate.  -tda
content.protection: For the left practice crack (cams to 3")For the right practice crack (cams from #0 metolius to 3.5")

climbs.name: Capitol Flake
climbs.fa: Jocelyn and Bob Van Belle  Spring 1994

content.description: Climb a hand, wide hand and fist  crack behind a jagged flake to a two bolt rap anchor.  This is mostly wide hands, I found the crux to be at the top getting to the anchor.  The nature of the flake gives this route an exposed feel.  Good desert climbing.
content.location: This route is about 25-30 yards left of BFF in Grand Wash and a hop, skip & a jump from a short 5.9 finger corner. It is just right of a chimney and leaning pillar.  See overview photo.

content.description: Left leaning hand crack that starts in so not so glamorous rock and ends in a dicey off-width.
content.protection: Bring mainly hand sized pieces with a few larger pieces for the off-width at the top.
content.location: This route is a couple hundred yards west of the practice cracks.
